awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: General and Modular Secure Computation in the Offline-Online Paradigm
awd_abstract_narration:
Secure multi-party computation (MPC) allows mutually distrusting parties to securely compute over their private data. The goal of this project is to provide novel MPC solutions that are efficient and simultaneously support operations of varying complexity on the input under their respective native representations. Driven by efficiency goals, this project studies the theory of MPC protocol design in the offline-online paradigm.  The outcomes of this project have the potential to produce practical and scalable MPC protocols that find applications in diverse fields like privacy-preserving data mining, mechanism design and distributed linear algebra computations.

This project defines the theory of computational correlations, leverages security guarantees to argue computational hardness results, and introduces the concept of computational channels in design and analysis of practical obvious transfer protocols. This theory could enable the transfer of the mature toolkit of information-theoretic techniques to the computationally bounded setting. Training the next generation of cryptography research and security professionals is a central goal of this project. The initiatives include design and development of new courses and course materials for undergraduate and graduate courses, and engagement of minority and women students in research. The project also develops active learning materials for the dissemination of knowledge.

por.por_cntn:
Secure computation is a fundamental cryptographic primitive that enables mutually distrusting parties to compute over their private data securely. Adversarial attacks on MPC protocols are getting increasingly more innovative and sophisticated. We need new MPC solutions to protect against these strong adversarial attacks and understand the limits of security ensured by existing MPC solutions against them. The objective is to minimize the overhead of security while simultaneously providing provable security. The research studies the limits of (qualitative and quantitative) MPC efficiency and simultaneously identifies the most devastating adversarial attacks.

The technical innovations of the research include the following specific contributions.

A) Efficient MPC via Multiplication Embeddings. MPC tasks encoded using Boolean circuits or arithmetic gates employ diverse techniques. Our innovation is an encoding that effortless and efficiently enables the interconversion among Boolean and arithmetic gates.

B) Computational hardness of guaranteeing output delivery. The refusal of adversarial parties to proceed with MPC protocols should not preclude honest parties from getting output. Our research demonstrates that expensive public-key primitives are necessary to provide such desirable features in MPC protocols.

C) MPC with Leakage-resilience. MPC protocols can no longer assume that cryptosystems are impervious blackboxes. Innovative side-channel attacks have repetitively falsified this assumption. Our research studies MPC techniques to ensure resilience against such attacks (even unforeseen ones) and simultaneously studies the additional security of existing MPC solutions against these attacks.

D) Limits of efficiency of MPC in the presence of leakage. The grand objective is to identify information-theoretic bounds on the efficiency of secure MPC protocols against leakage attacks. The non-triviality lies in developing accurate bounds, i.e., they are achievable by protocols as well.

The research contributes to fundamental topics in mathematics (like discrete mathematics, algebraic geometry, harmonic analysis, probability theory) and information theory. These results introduce new technical innovations, unifying abstraction, and simplifying presentations of existing technical concepts. A new course, ``Mathematical toolkit in CS'' developed by the PI, covers several technical materials fundamental to the research outcomes. This course provides incoming graduate students and exceptional undergraduate students in CS (and related departments) a bootstrapping course on fundamental mathematics and theoretical computer science topics. The research conducted in this project was presented at top peer-reviewed research venues. This project also enabled the training of multiple graduate students in advanced mathematics, information theory, and secure computation. Furthermore, the research has produced highly efficient secure computation protocols, which may bring secure computation closer to deployment in broader applications in the real world.
